thread.title: Upset gets RPI untracked
thread.title_full: Upset gets RPI untracked - Times Union

author: Matt Graves
title: Upset gets RPI untracked
text:
Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI Image 1 of / 11 Caption

(Paul Buckowski / Times Union)
Buy this photo Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI RPI's Jake Wood, left, and Travis Fulton, right, force the puck... Image 3 of 11 RPI's Jason Kasdorf makes a save during their game against Boston College on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015, in Troy, N.Y. (Paul Buckowski / Times Union)
Buy this photo Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI RPI's Jason Kasdorf makes a save during their game against Boston... Image 4 of 11 RPI's Bradley Bell fights Boston College players for control of the puck during their game on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015, in Troy, N.Y. (Paul Buckowski / Times Union)
Buy this photo Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI RPI's Bradley Bell fights Boston College players for control of the... Image 5 of 11 RPI's Bradley Bell, center, fights Boston College players for control of the puck during their game on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015, in Troy, N.Y. (Paul Buckowski / Times Union)
Buy this photo Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI RPI's Bradley Bell, center, fights Boston College players for... Image 6 of 11 RPI's Jesper Ohrvall brings the puck up the ice during their game against Boston College on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015, in Troy, N.Y. (Paul Buckowski / Times Union)
Buy this photo Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI RPI's Jesper Ohrvall brings the puck up the ice during their game... Image 7 of 11 RPI's Travis Fulton looks to make a pass during their game against Boston College on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015, in Troy, N.Y. (Paul Buckowski / Times Union)
Buy this photo Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI RPI's Travis Fulton looks to make a pass during their game against... Image 8 of 11 RPI's Viktor Liljegren brings the puck up the ice during their game against Boston College on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015, in Troy, N.Y. (Paul Buckowski / Times Union)
Buy this photo Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI RPI's Viktor Liljegren brings the puck up the ice during their game... Image 9 of 11 RPI's Jake Wood hits Boston College's Colin White into the boards during their game on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015, in Troy, N.Y. (Paul Buckowski / Times Union)
Buy this photo Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI RPI's Jake Wood hits Boston College's Colin White into the boards... Image 10 of 11 RPI's Mike Prapavessis, left, tries to force the puck away from a Boston College player during their game on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015, in Troy, N.Y. (Paul Buckowski / Times Union)
Buy this photo Photo: PAUL BUCKOWSKI RPI's Mike Prapavessis, left, tries to force the puck away from a... Image 11 of 11 Upset gets RPI untracked 1 / 11 Back to Gallery Troy
If Sunday's home opener against the top-ranked team in the country was to serve as a barometer for RPI's coming season, the forecast would have to be considered sunny with a reasonable chance of success.
The Engineers, picked to finish 10th in the ECAC, shocked No. 1 Boston College 2-1 Sunday at Houston Field House in one of the biggest upsets of the Seth Appert era in Troy.
Junior Riley Bourbonnais scored both goals for RPI (1-1-0) and senior goaltender Jason Kasdorf was brilliant in the nets with 36 saves as the Engineers held off the team with the most drafted players (13) of any college team in the country. It marked the fourth consecutive time RPI beat BC in this building, the last time 20 years ago.
More Information
RPI 2, Boston College 1
BC 0 0 1 — 1
RPI 0 1 1 — 2
First period — No scoring. Penalties—Tironese, RPI (interference) 4:08; Calnan, BC (holding) 8:15; Calnan, BC (tripping) 12:21.
Second period—1, RPI, Bourbonnais 1 (Tironese, Reno) 19: 14. Penalties—Gaudreau, BC (interference) 6:54; Bubela, RPI (boarding) 8:58; Tironese, RPI (tripping) 13:00.
Third Period—2, RPI, Bourbonnais 2 (Tironese, Wilson) 3: 02 (pp). 3, Boston College, Sanford 2 (Doherty, Tuch) 8:36 (pp). Penalties—Fitzgerald, BC (elbowing) 1:45; Liljegren, RPI (hooking) 4:38; Wilson, RPI (slashing) 7:28.
Shots on goal—Boston College 13-16-8—37. RPI 13-7-8--28.
Power-play opportunities—BC 1-for-5. RPI 1-for-4.
Goaltenders—Boston College, Demko 1-1-0 (28 shots-26 saves). RPI, Kasdorf 0-1-0 (37-36).
T—2: 04. A— 2,770.
"It's an awesome feeling," said Bourbonnais, who scored a hat trick against Union College a little more than a year ago. "There's nothing better than that. You know you're up 2-nothing there and the team's going, so it's just great. We need to get better, but it's great momentum going into Alaska (Brice Alaska Gold Rush tournament) next weekend.
After a scoreless first period during which both teams took 13 shots, RPI continued to play great defense and ride the stellar goaltending of Kasdorf into the second period, finally getting rewarded with less than 56 seconds remaining.
Bourbonnais took a pass from freshman Evan Tironese and fired a shot from the right circle that goalie Thatcher Demko couldn't locate with Tironese following in to screen the goaltender. It was RPI's first goal of the season after a 3-0 loss at Lowell on Friday.
Kasdorf, meanwhile, stopped all 16 shots he faced in the middle period, his best saves coming on a six-shot flurry during a relentless BC power play at the 13-minute mark.
Bourbonnais made it 2-0 at 3:02 of the third period when he scored in the slot on a power play, taking the assist from Tironese again. It stayed that way until Zach Sanford cut the lead in half on a power play for BC at 8:36, beating Kasdorf at the right post.
The Eagles, the defending NCAA champions, called a timeout with 1:20 to play and replaced Demko with a sixth skater, but Kasdorf and a pesky defense kept them at bay to secure the victory.
"I thought it was a good game," said veteran BC coach Jerry York. "Our compete level was excellent. We had a lot of opportunities, but just the one goal. RPI players blocked a lot of shots (45) and Kasdorf made some really good saves. Credit their defense; credit their blocking shots. They're a good club and they competed well."
The last time the Engineers beat a top-ranked team came on Jan. 29, 2011 when they defeated Yale 5-2 in the Big Red Freakout.
"It was just a good win," Appert understated. "You're not playing the schedule that we have in front of us because we expect to go undefeated. You're playing it to test yourselves against the best teams in the country. Jason (Kasdorf) was what Jason is; he's our rock. You had two of the best goalies in college hockey going head-to-head today."
Matt Graves is a freelance writer.
